div.p: We present potential approaches for implementing secure embedded intelligence (SEI) and integrated state awareness (ISA) in advanced nuclear energy (NE) systems. A framework for deliberate design and operations of such systems is provided, and potential risks, challenges and impacts discussed. Activities that should be carried out in research, development, and demonstration (RD&D) opportunities are identified. Resulting implications for operation of 'smart nuclear systems', including remote operations, flexible operations, predictive maintenance, inherent digital security, and autonomous controls, are discussed.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The use of energy resources is dramatically changing in multiple aspects, including moving from centralized to distributed topologies, from fixed to flexible generation, from dispatchable to non-dispatchable (renewable) energy sources (e.g., solar, wind, geothermal), and from constant to highly-variable loads (e.g., electric vehicles). Thus, the energy environments in which NE must compete are becoming highly diverse, uncertain, and dynamic. To accommodate these more stringent conditions at a competitive cost, smart nuclear systems (SNS) have been proposed exhibiting intelligence behavior enabled by two cornerstone notions, namely, SEI and ISA (Garcia et al., 2019).

Fig. 1 illustrates the relationship between these notions and the technologies whose rapid advances have made possible their cost-effective implementation: ubiquitous sensing, data analytics, reasoning, intelligent controls, and hybrid (physics-based plus data-driven) modeling and simulation (M&S). Going from left to right in this figure, data is collected from the monitored systems, structures, and components (SSC) through adaptive sensing and, after their appropriate manipulation and interpretation by SEIand ISA-driven processes closely working together in cooperation, commands are executed through adaptive actuation on the monitored SSC at the right. These SEI-and ISA-driven processes are sustained by advanced technologies related to data analytics, reasoning, intelligent controls, and hybrid modeling and simulation (M&S). The bidirectional arrows for sensing and actuation denotes that the sensor and actuation networks used for collecting data from and acting on the monitored SSC, respectively, may accordingly vary at the direction of SEI and ISA to respond to observed or predicted SSC conditions. Via SEI and ISA, adaptation of sensing, actuation, and hence operations is possible, allowing SNS to cost-effectively compete in time-varying energy grids subjected to hybrid (digital plus physical) insults.

A key objective of SEI is to provide ISA and automated reasoning while ensuring digital security and resiliency, thus bringing the game-changing abilities of digital sciences to advanced reactor concepts using an integrated (as opposed to bolt-on) approach. If achieved, SEI-ISA would provide game-changing implications for systems maintainability, operability (autonomous, semiautonomous, or remote control), digital security and resiliency, and lower-cost expansion of NE applications due to operations simplicity and cost reduction. RD&D associated with SEI-ISA for nuclear systems could be a major contribution to NE technology deployment for the energy markets of the future.

Smart functionalities (e.g., autonomous operations) can now be safely and cost-effectively introduced in the nuclear industry, including into microreactor designs. A microreactor is understood here as reactors smaller than 20 MWth, which is about 2-3 thousandth the size of a typical commercial light-water reactors (LWR) built today. Thus, the concept of nuclear microreactors supplying heat to reconfigurable power conversion systems is envisioned as a resilient energy system that can meet energy demands for on-and off-the-grid as well as for industrial applications. Small, stackable nuclear microreactors, with multiple units potentially located on a common site, could also be arranged in a plug-and-play configuration to a reactor-agnostic power conversion system. Nuclear microreactors are viewed as a competitive option for NE due to several benefits, including their reliance on economies of multiples (as opposed to scale), phased introduction at locations with shared common facilities, and ability to optimize investment recovery, Microreactors can also be readily integrated within hybrid energy systems (HES) (see e.g., Binder et al., 2017;Garcia et al., 2016;Garcia et al., 2013a;Garcia et al., 2013b) deployed for facilitating clean energy integration, thus offering the possibility of reestablishing a competitive US nuclear industry (Lovering et al., 2018).

Unattended systems with minimal maintenance, high reliability, and passive safety features are also attractive options for remote areas, forward operating military bases (FOB), merchant vessels, disaster relief, or humanitarian missions. Expected to reduce system complexity and facilitate the implementation passive safety concepts, microreactors are poised to promote the implementation of SEI-driven monitoring and control (M&C) approaches supporting attractive possibilities (e.g., unattended operation without critical human intervention). Key definitions addressed here follow.

div.head: Secure embedded intelligence (SEI)
div.p: Embedded intelligence (EI), a generational disruptor, denotes the embedding of sensing, actuation, and intelligence capabilities into SSC that enable or facilitate intelligent behaviors in complex engineered systems interacting with dynamic environments to extract the greatest value. On the other hand, SEI denotes the inherently-secured implementation of EI techniques and technologies in cyber-physical systems (CPS) assuming at the outset that these CPS may be challenged by disturbances and threats, nonmalicious and malicious, of well-or ill-defined characterizations.

Intelligent capabilities include features for learning, reasoning, and adapting to dynamic situations. By promoting generalization, abstraction, discovery, and association, an engineered system with EI has the ability to recognize important patterns in its processes and operations, interpret what these patterns mean with respect to its mission and state condition, and adjust its processes in real-time to maintain efficient, safe, and secure operations. The fact that security is intrinsically considered during the design, development, and implementation of EI techniques within nuclear systems is unique when compared with traditional designs, which consider only natural disturbances of well-defined characterizations. SSC designed with SEI exhibit inherent digital security and resiliency.

div.head: Integrated state-space awareness (ISA)
div.p: ISA, a generational disruptor as well, denotes the ability to perceive the states, attributes, and dynamics of all relevant SSC, comprehend their current situations and conditions, and predict their states based on assumed future operations.

div.head: Smart nuclear systems (SNS)
div.p: An SNS denotes a nuclear system with the ability to autonomously monitor, reason, learn, control, and improve its own conditions and performance (and possibly those of others) while operating in dynamic environments subjected to intentional and non-intentional physical and digital disturbances.

Toward achieving smart functionalities (e.g., self-control, selfprotection, self-healing, and self-improvement), SNS require the ubiquitous integration of SEI techniques (including multi-agent data analysis mechanisms) to enhance many of the regulating functions currently performed by traditional controls. Their ability to achieve ISA of operations exert an unprecedented impact in autonomy and (artificial or machine) reasoning, substantially lowering operations and maintenance (O&M) costs, while assuring high safety and security postures. A key distinction in SNS is their full utilization of knowledge regarding themselves augmented by learning from experience and of feedbacks with justified beliefs resulting from their own actions to provide reliable, safe, and secure controls in accordance with assigned missions or priorities. However, SNS may necessitate a radical change in present regulatory structures and philosophies.

Fig. 2 illustrates relationships among the key notions addressed in this article. In particular, SNS are nuclear systems that offer a number of smart functionalities opened by the realization of ISA, which is enabled by the ubiquitous use of SEI. The cost-effective achievement of SEI in nuclear systems with robust digital security and resiliency as well as with engineering designs that facilitate automated and predictive physical maintenance of SSC stands on nine technological thrusts as follows:

1. Intelligent autonomous frameworks and agents 2. Hyper-layered modeling and distributed digital replication 3. Embedded smart sensing and actuation devices 4. Adaptive security architectures 5. Human-machine interfaces 6. Augmented analytics and machine learning (ML) 7. Advanced edge computing and communication 8. Integrated testing platforms 9. Regulatory research

div.head: Organization of paper
div.p: The remaining sections of this paper are organized as follows. Section 2 describes the approach of SEI-by-design in which SEI is addressed right at the start of the design phases of an SNS. Section 3 discusses technical opportunities for achieving the implementation of SEI and ISA in SNS and suggests potential architectures, approaches, and methods for their realization. Section 4 concludes the article.

div.head: Approach: SEI-by-design
div.p: The use of SEI should be addressed at the start of the design phases of advanced nuclear systems to determine the intelligence required to successfully achieve SEI-by-design and result in optimal ISA. A key aspect of SEI-by-design is devising smart functionality as a principle aspect of the design, which may change the original physical design itself. Multiple factors can influence the degree of intelligence needed in a design, including:

1. Desired design simplicity 2. Smart functionalities 3. Goals, requirements, and considerations for identified metrics (e.g., performance, health, risk) 4. Constraints of identified technologies 5. Complexity of target application 6. Level of automation Similarly, the introduction of SEI and ISA in nuclear designs should be analyzed in the context of:

1. Activity-level economic analysis: This context analyzes the benefit and costs of the individual activities regardless of the reactor mission. The cost of some activities might be distributed among multiple tasks and therefore need to be considered in a holistic manner. For example, introducing particular data infrastructures could result in benefits to several automated activities using SEI. 2. Reactor-level economic analysis: This context analyzes the benefit and cost of the smart functionalities facilitated by SEI and ISA. This impacts the cost-saving resulting from automating activities that might not be as attractive if considered independently, but are necessary to achieve the overall cost-saving resulting from the application of technology to the energy market. 3. Fleet-level economic analysis: This context analyzes the benefit and cost of implementing multiple reactors in a connected grid of energy sources, and the ability of the reactors to perform multiple functions depending on the energy demands at any point of time.

The economic analysis at each level of evaluation requires a hierarchical cost-analysis approach that would be specific to the considered scope and may build on existing efforts that targets the three levels of economic analysis mentioned above. Activitylevel economic analysis would benefit from the ongoing work performed for LWRs (Thomas et al., 2016). Reactor-level economic analysis would gain from reactor-technology-specific economic benefits (e.g., DOE, 2014). Fleet-level economic analysis would benefit from energy optimization efforts performed in multiple Department of Energy (DOE) efforts (e.g., Bragg-Sitton et al., 2016).

Technologies developed under SEI-by-design will reside at different levels of complexity within M&C systems. Fig. 3 depicts a typical functional layering in complex industrial control systems (ICS), with the envisioned intelligent system performing data acquisition, monitoring, verification, validation, evaluation, correction, and reporting of measurements, decisions, and actions at each level. In particular, going from the bottom to the top, the lowest level consists of the (field) sensors and actuators interacting with the physical assets (e.g., nuclear core, energy conversion systems, equipment) to monitor and control a given nuclear SSC as determined by the inner and outer (local, low-level) controllers located at the control level. The supervisory layer, including the operations and production levels, has a larger view of the monitored SSC and coordinates the operation of a set of local controllers by providing them with setpoints that must be tracked. The tactical level contains algorithms supporting plant execution processes, including prognostics and health management (PHM) functions. The strategic level conducts optimization routines considering metrics, objectives, and requirements defined for the monitored CPS to determine the optimal plant settings based on a system-centric perspective of the monitored plant and the conditions existing and predicted for the surrounding environment and energy resources connected to it. The last level, management information system interconnects the operational technology (OT) processes (including control functions) with the information technology (IT) processes (including business functions). The ubiquitous use of SEI at all levels and appropriate implementation of security and resiliency in them are discussed next as they relate to SEI deployment within different elements in SSC.

div.head: Technological thrusts
div.p: The framework and methods proposed for the deployment of SNS are designed within a RD&D opportunity space organized into nine technological thrusts as shown in Fig. 2. The motivation for these thrusts is to provide a structure that encapsulates major scientific disciplines that are central to achieving the ubiquitous implementation of SEI and ISA in nuclear systems following an SEI-by-design approach. This section provides a general discussion regarding these eight thrusts for achieving the implementation of SEI and ISA in SNS and suggests potential architectures, approaches, and methods for their realization.

div.head: Intelligent autonomous frameworks and agents
div.p: This thrust involves the development and validation of complete and scalable modules that can be deployed in nuclear systems for realizing smart functionalities attended by intelligent, autonomous agents supporting M&C tasks. These intelligent agents will be responsible to embed SEI-driven techniques and technologies in passive and active SSC.

For implementing SEI and ISA in nuclear systems, a modular, flexible, scalable, and secure architecture, along with its computational and communication platforms, is necessary to support multiple modern functions such as:

1. Fault-tolerance and risk-informed operations 2. State awareness and health management 3. Learning, reasoning, adaptation to dynamic conditions 4. Security and resiliency To develop suitable functional frameworks and foundational components in support of these functions, an autonomous M&C framework is envisioned that includes the key functional concepts of system, mission, and cognition, along with the six system components illustrated in Fig. 4 and listed below:

1. Mission 2. Knowledge databases 3. Condition and pattern assessment 4. Integrated state awareness and automated reasoning (ISAR) 5. Intelligent and resilient controls 6. Smart actuation and sensor networks Fig. 4 is intended to represent a notional functional framework identifying six foundational components assessed as crucial for the implementation of intelligent M&C systems in SNS. Thus, Fig. 4 does not explicitly identify the location(s) or degree(s) of complexity related to each component, but their existence. In general, each of these system components may be distributed and hosted at different locations and computational platforms existing across different SSC. Likewise, each foundational component may extend to several of the levels depicted in Fig. 3. While sensing and actuation are restricted to reside at the field level of Fig. 3, a particular intelligent control may be realized in a manner that extends to the control, production, and operations levels. Similarly, knowledge databases may consist of a networked assembly of local databases placed at edge components (e.g., valves or pumps having the computational power necessary for both making decisions and storing knowledge at the edge), constructed from data-driven models, and implemented in co-located memory chips as well as on global databases located at centralized data clusters, constructed from high-fidelity physics-based models, and implemented on highperformance computing (HPC) platforms. A portable, flexible, and scalable architecture is of interest here, one that can be applied to diverse nuclear system designs (e.g., microreactors).

These system components may be constructed and integrated using multi-agent systems (MAS) technology, an approach for developing loosely coupled autonomous systems, where each intelligent agent pursues its goals while employing standardsconforming messaging to interact with other agents. This fault tolerant approach has several advantages. If one agent fails in its task, for example, it does not necessarily affect or degrade the others in the system, thus maintaining expected levels of robustness, extensibility, and graceful degradation. The multiplicity of alternative control solutions and communication options will enhance the flexibility and adaptability of nuclear systems. The integration of multiple mission-directed intelligent agents within an intelligent M&C architecture paves the way to the realization of SNS. However, such an integration of disparate intelligent agents will require a standard approach to building and deploying individual components and functionalities. Thus, effective and scalable interoperability is a key facet for achieving smart functionalities. The components of this intelligent monitoring and control framework are discussed below.

div.head: Framework components for intelligent M&C
div.p: 1) Mission: The notion of mission (or repository of O&M objectives) is of paramount importance to support autonomous con- trol frameworks for SNS. This would require an unambiguous definition of a top-level mission, or objective to be achieved, for the monitored SSC, together with its subordinated goals and associated planning routines. However, traditional implementations of control strategies emphasize the achievement of local control objectives by using multiple, often disassociated inner and outer control loops. This strategy often results in high-precision responses, possibly at the expense of increased brittleness in the design. A practical strategy to eliminate brittleness and increase mission-level security and resilience is to make engineered systems robust 'at the mission level' with regard to these properties . This strategy can be made effective by partially transferring the responsibility of real-time decision-making behavior from operators to the control systems themselves during operations, and is enabled by SEI.

A key metric for quantification and tracking at the mission level is risk, which can be formulated to assess whether a given SSC is meeting its mission and to otherwise drive control actions in a manner toward reducing residual risk. In this regard, Fig. 5 illustrates a hierarchical architecture of a mission-driven M&C technology, comprising five layers that include some of the foundational components depicted in Fig. 4, except two components. The first is the ''knowledge and risk assessment" (envisioned within the ''knowledge database" component of Fig. 4), which encapsulates characterizations defining risk and conditions for the given nuclear SSC as data is collected. The second is the ''awareness and optimization" component (envisioned within the ISAR component of Fig. 4) and including multiobjective optimization algorithms to identify best solutions to meet the specified system mission in the face of dynamic (possibly uncertain) operating conditions. The ''condition assessment and control" component updates health characterizations embedded within this component as measurements, assessments (e.g., from PHM systems), and commands are received. With assessments on the conditions of the monitored SSC received from the ''condition assessment and control" component, the ''knowledge and risk assessment" component computes metrics and probabilities useful for decision-making and planning to maintain the monitored SSC within an acceptable residual risk, albeit in a degraded manner as needed. Computation of risk is enabled by a dynamic risk assessment model embedded within this component, which includes formulations of aging, degradation, and malfunctioning of critical SSC. Thus, component characterizations may include aspects regarding cybersecurity, such as whether a given informational component (e.g., sensor, controller) may have been compromised, which may occur with some level of certainty and with the risk reflecting how sure of failure the SSC is and including flexible tolerances to provide flexible cost-efficient security. Using information collected from the ''mission" and ''knowledge and risk assessment" components, the ''awareness and optimization" component uses multiattribute, multi-objective algorithms to determine optimal actions to best achieve specified mission objectives. To balance performance against O&M costs, for example, the ''awareness and optimization" component may decide to execute life extension control actions and operate an aging SSC at a reduced load until the next convenient maintenance cycle can be conducted without affecting safety criteria despite suboptimal performance.

2) Knowledge databases: The approach of explicitly embedding the notion of knowledge (and with it, knowledge databases) within the notional architecture of Fig. 4 is of key significance toward building ISA and supporting reasoning and optimization on the actual state and understanding of monitored SSC. Knowledge databases span the entire life-cycle digital thread and lifetime of the SSC of focus, with its digital siblings distributively deployed. Assimilated knowledge can be used during operations to evaluate numerous aspects of system state, including: 1. Estimation and prediction of the conditions, states, and patterns or behaviors of SSC relative to a given mission 2. Determination, with the assistance of a multi-objective optimization functionality, of how control elements can be utilized to accommodate the assessed plant conditions and stay focused toward best fulfilling the specified mission for which the given engineered system was designed. Application specific knowledge is contained in this component, with knowledge representations secured and stored in (distributed) knowledge databases, which are fundamental for organizing and supporting intelligent functions. These knowledge databases contain not only information about the monitored SSC, but also knowledge extracted from experts and operators in a manner that represents inputs. This information may include mathematical models characterizing known dynamics of the given SSC and data-driven models learned or augmented from observing and analyzing plant operations. Consequently, the knowledge databases may be constituted by a set of distributed model databases of diverse complexity, granularity, and intelligence interconnected by communication links as illustrated in Fig. 6. Supporting a hyper-layered M&C approach developed under the ''Hyper-layered modeling and distributed digital replication" trust to be discussed in Section 3.2, this multidimensional, hyper-layered modeling portfolio constituting the knowledge databases may be organized into a hierarchy of networked models of diverse fidelity, complexity, and scope characterizing different objects as illustrated in Fig. 7. A distributed digital twins (DDT) approach is proposed. To make them work in cooperation, knowledge databases should be equipped, not only with episodic memory consisting of a series of loosely connected parts or events, but also with advanced representation constructs and contents that can be accessed and manipulated to support explanations generated by embedded intelligent agents, including larger-scale structures for recording states, plans, actions, and execution traces. Intelligent agents will then access and extract content from this memory to generate and revise plans and to communicate and answer questions about decisions and reasoning, providing information such as progressions regarding plan execution and events that led to executed plans. In this way, the notional strategy for embedding and manipulating knowledge extends the use of fixed engineering models to run-time models that may be altered and exploited by collected data and SEI-assisted elements, including embedded intelligent autonomous agents. Data in local or global databases may be accessed by diverse autonomous agents at any time to perform statistical and inference analysis on process data, which can be used to support assessments, decisions, and controls. Thus, the databases conferring this knowledge can be in constant network communication, allowing knowledge inference information to be passed from one intelligent agent (e.g., an observer, or controller) to another. The ubiquitous use of sensors embedded throughout monitored SSC will also generate significant volumes of data, which may impose unique requirements in data transmission and storage. A robust and flexible data communication (wired and wireless), management, and storage strategy and framework will be needed to support smart functionalities. The use of the proposed DDT approach may also allow synthetic sensing, and reduction of sensor required for a given observability state of a design, which could provide significant advantage and cost reduction. 3) Condition and pattern assessment: The condition and pattern assessment component updates global and local knowledge databases based on estimations and predictions regarding SSC conditions and states. This component assesses operational data collected from sensing devices. These assessments are then utilized to update the estimations regarding system-states of the SSC contained in corresponding knowledge databases. Collected data may not only include information generated by the monitored SSC themselves, but also events occurring outside of them to make better digital and physical assessments of asset conditions and to issue timely decisions. Data generated by sensors distributed throughout SSC are used by this component to construct diagnostics and prognostics techniques, potentially constructed as hybrid implementations combining physicsbased and data-driven models, to assess and predict the conditions of selected SSC. Diagnostic processes will be typically conducted for anomaly/condition detection, isolation, mode identification, and assessment. Prognostic processes will be conducted for health metric (e.g., remaining-useful-life, RUL) prediction toward estimating the time a given SSC may no longer perform its particular function. For example, early leak detection may be accomplished by measuring pressure, flow, acoustic, electromagnetic, mechanical, chemical, thermal, and other quantifiable attributes. The system then examines the estimated states and searches for anomalies that may suggest the presence of a leak. Similarly, advanced corrosion analytics using data, physics-based models, and ML can be used to estimate the corrosion conditions and associated health metrics of key SSC. International Organization for Standardization (ISO) definitions for fault diagnostics and prognostics can be found in ISO (2012), ISO (2011), andISO (2005). In support of improved security, ML and deep learning technologies may be used to extract information from OT data infrastructures to detect digital and physical threats, determine the vulnerability landscape, and deploy corrections. In conclusion, multiple key performance indices (KPI) may be defined and tracked during operations. 4) Integrated state awareness and automated reasoning: The integrated state awareness and automated reasoning (ISAR) component uses embedded knowledge during operations to evaluate the estimated conditions of SSC in relation to the system mission, to reason about its mission, to solve identified issues using acquired knowledge via inference, and to determine how control elements may be utilized to accommodate assessed plant conditions and stay focused on fulfilling the mission, even if this can only be accomplished in a suboptimal or degraded manner. Consequently, it is the point at which mission-and risk-informed decisions are made, using the information stored in the knowledge databases and information computed from optimization to arrive at decisions, while executing all applicable rules associated with the monitored SSC. By interrogating the knowledge databases and understanding system mission, this foundational component makes the system aware of its current state in relation to its mission, detects when system behaviors drift away from achieving mission objectives, and ascertains potential actions for directing system behaviors so they converge toward mission achievement. To facilitate reasoning processes, formal ontological elements may be used to model diverse domains of knowledge (Sanz et al., 2017).

Given received instructions, this reasoning engine relies on goal-directed autonomous agents that may generate plans using problem-space searching techniques, carry out selected plans, and adapt plans as the need arises with little or no human interaction. The automated reasoning engine also interacts with the global database to analyze collected data about the monitored SSC and support additional automated reasoning activities during operations toward improving other functionalities and operations involving the manipulation of knowledge such as: 1. Conducting state estimation, prediction, consolidation 2. Assessing performance quality toward achieving mission 3. Supporting actions and adaptation of sensor and controller configurations 4. Executing re-design actions 5. Supporting reconfiguration of SSC whenever their behavior deviates from the mission in an analogous way, or better, in the ways an operator might respond. Thus, the ISAR component closes the loop between actual system performance and mission requirements to maintain the desired system behavior even in the presence of disturbances, failures, or attacks, whether natural or malicious. As more intelligent systems conducting knowledge interpretation, inference, and reasoning connect and interact among themselves, more evidences are constructed to improve state awareness and reasoning processes, further confirming the actual states of the monitored SSC and the effectiveness of identified actions. As instructions and actions are carried out by autonomous intelligent systems, it is fundamental to building trust and confidence in the ubiquitous application of SEI in nuclear systems that agents are made capable of describing, explaining, and justifying their decisions and actions to human partners, including reveling every aspect of their reasoning and decision-making processes. This desired ability for autonomous agents to explain the reasoning that produced selections has been referred as explainable agency (Langley et al., 2017). As an element of ISAR, an intelligent agent equipped with explainable agency should be able to clarify how chosen decisions relate to made inferences, adopted goals, and generated plans, as well as, if applicable, how its decisions were adapted for selecting alternative responses when observed events appear to diverge from the selected plan. In particular, four abilities have been identified in Langley et al. (2017) that provide the basics of explainable agency:

1. Capable of explaining decisions made during plan generation, including producing records of them; 2. Capable of communicating actions conducted during plan execution; 3. Capable of explaining adapted responses during plan monitoring whenever actual events may have diverged from selected plans; 4. Capable of communicating decisions and reasons, including producing reports on reasoning activities and answers to questions about choices. These capabilities present a significant challenge for the research community at large; limited research has been undertaken on this important topic of explainable agency despite the growing need for it in applications demanding SEI. 5) Intelligent and resilient controls: Industries, including nuclear power, use a large spectrum of traditional control algorithms ranging from proportional, integral, and derivative (PID) controllers to advanced predictive-based controllers such as robust control and model predictive control (MPC). However, traditional control algorithms require careful analysis of process dynamics, development of mathematical models characterizing main governing dynamics, and synthesis of control laws that meet specified requirements under wellcharacterized constraints and disturbances. A main drawback of using these mature and well-proven control algorithms is related to the potentially highly complexity of dynamic models. Traditional control techniques will need to be revamped to handle the enhanced complexity. The current trend is to use hybrid control strategies that combine traditional, physics-based control algorithms, synthesized from known process dynamics, with data-driven control algorithms synthesized from process dynamics learned from data using techniques such as ML (Murphy, 2012). The concept of adaptive control with ML is a potentially powerful tool for application in advanced nuclear systems, particularly so if standardized nuclear systems are deployed and monitored for relevant data of promising applicability to nuclear systems. Challenges, such as regulations view on non-physics based models and analysis, need to be resolved for enabling this ML-enhanced control in SNS. Relying on intelligent control algorithms, the control element is responsible for generating proper actions by using collected data, instructions issued by the ISAR component, communications exchanged among controllers, information and rules about possible actions contained in knowledge bases, and action-generation knowledge (e.g., forward heuristic planners, adversary models, vulnerability analysis). Actions are then sent to actuators that execute them. The augmented responsibility of modern control elements is, not only to maintain given control objectives under dynamic conditions so that controlled variables track set points, but also to regulate KPI within specified ranges throughout the entire operation process. The unique control strategy introduced here is that metrics are defined and then quantified during operations to have a quantitative picture of where a given monitored SSC is and where it is going. Importance indices (II) that need to be included within KPI are typically defined by the application at hand. KPI could also characterize mission targets or constraints. Overall process optimization can then be executed through the integration of system inputs and target KPI to maximize. Typical KPI may include risk, efficiency, safety, security, cost and profit, energy production quality, component health conditions, physical properties and compositions for different process streams, and environmental requirements. Fig. 8 illustrates an SEI-driven architecture for implementing Intelligent and resilient controls in nuclear SSC. In particular, given: i) specific KPI, metrics, and objective functions embedded within the mission; ii) characterizations, requirements, and constraints embedded in the knowledge database component; and iii) performance assessments computed from feedback information, the state awareness and reasoning engine issues control strategies and conflict resolution directives to regulate the operation of Intelligent and resilient controls in order to meet system-centric performance objectives. This sort of Intelligent and resilient control is now feasible with the advent of SEI advances.

div.head: Hyper-layered modeling and distributed digital replication
div.p: This thrust involves the development and validation of advanced hyper-layered M&S capabilities to support 'hyperlayered M&C' enabling multiple predictive features, such as PHM, digital replication (DDR), and predictive maintenance (PM). It also accelerates the creation of multiple, distributed models to be used in support of diverse smart functionalities such as self-validation, self-optimization, and self-protection.

A variety of SSC models may be used to support smart functionalities, including monitoring, control, reasoning, and decision-making, with proper selection of the appropriate models being crucial to increasing model robustness, reducing uncertainty, improving precision, and reducing cost. The ability to model SSC will create new opportunities to more completely digitize nuclear operations and implement revolutionary concepts such as ISA. The concept of using hyper-layered models to simulate SSC or the entire nuclear enterprise allows SNS to better predict behaviors and to respond with much greater agility to numerous disturbances in materials and environment, in maintenance, and from malicious attacks. Computational techniques support many functionalities. Examples include PM, condition-based maintenance (CBM), fault detection and isolation (FDI), advanced controls, and risk-informed decision-making.

Based on methods used to derive models, three main approaches can be identified: physics-based, data-driven, and hybrid models. Model derivation typically comes from an understanding of the main physical phenomena and relationships governing the behavior of the monitored SSC. A physics-based model is typically developed based on this understanding by translating it into formulations in the form of a combination of algebraic, ordinary, or/and partial differential equations. However, deriving physics-based models may be very challenging due to system complexity, a need to have expert knowledge, and the potential existence of stochastic mechanisms pertaining to SSC. In complex SSC, physics-based approaches may not be applicable because performing online measurements may be impractical and even impossible. Models can also be derived from data by constructing adequate (e.g., simple to complex) mappings that can relate inputs to outputs using information from condition monitoring data collected via installed sensors. As SSC become more complex and issues related to data imprecision and uncertainty are more pervasive and challenging, data-driven models have gained significant traction recently, especially because of their ability to understand highly-coupled systems, typical in nuclear systems. However, the accuracy of data-driven approaches depends on the data available and quantification of uncertainty remains difficult.

To meet broader requirements and applications, hybrid systems are often preferred. The current trend is to develop hybrids of modeling and analytical approaches because no single paradigm may be superior to the others in all situations, and integrated approaches tend to improve the 'overall model' by relying on strengths in the sub-models. In this approach, there is a possibility to capitalize on the respective strengths of each approach and address their weaknesses. A hybrid approach combines heterogeneous models to lever the advantages and integrate the merits of different approaches while minimizing their limitations toward making robust metric (e.g., RUL) estimations and predictions about the monitored SSC. In a hybrid model as illustrated in Fig. 9, mathematical equations are constructed characterizing the 'known, modeled' dynamics of the given SSC. Likewise, input/output relations are also embedded characterizing the unknown, un-modeled dynamics. Outputs from each approach are then combined to compute more accurate estimations and predictions regarding the SSC. How large or involved one portion is with respect to the other depends on the availability and abundance of data and costs associated in constructing each given characterization. It is typically beneficial to continually evaluate the predictive ability of each aspect of the hybrid model under different situations and using diverse predictive strategies by comparing formerly predicted states corresponding to different modeling aspects to the current system state and their observed changes. However, this relationship must run two ways as degradation/ performance of SSC and sensors must be accounted for in order to accurately estimate system state.

The selection of the model approach to use in support of managing complex systems is based on multiple factors, including the availability and abundance of data and the cost associated with developing it. Recognizing the availability of physics-based models associated with SSC and the new smart functionalities and opportunities offered by data-driven techniques such as ML, multiple industries have capitalized on the use of hybrid approaches. The application of hybrid techniques started long ago, is currently significant, and is expected to continue to grow. Several publications describe hybrid implementations (e.g., Vogl et al., 2016;Mishral et al., 2014;Galar et al., 2013;Ly et al., 2009;Medjaher et al., 2009;Bagul et al., 2008;Alpay et al., 2006;Venkatasubramanian, 2005;Vilim et al., 2001;Garcia and Vilim, 2000;Engel et al., 2000). For example, a review of hybrid prognostics approaches and a proposed hybrid framework for system RUL predictions are reported in Liao and Kottig (2014) and Liao and Kottig (2016). The benefits of hybrid models and techniques are many. Potential aspects are summarized below into four distinct areas:

1. Integrated state awareness (ISA). An outcome would be real-time predictive capability focused on ISA for the facility. This would allow ultimate management and control over system safety, operations, life-cycle risk management, and maintenance costs. 2. Digital-informed and antifragile design approach. The approach will incorporate digitally-informed design to achieve systems resilience, self-protection, and selfhealing among other smart functionalities. These techniques will be essential in assuring these digitallydriven systems remain secure and may advance the art of self-healing systems design. 3. Intelligence-derived safety. The use of hybrid approaches will enable massively embedded sensing, computing, and intelligence to provide an analogue to physicsbased inherent safety. Rather than relying on only physics principals for walk-away safety, a safe end-state may be achieved through highly-reliable predictive intelligence. 4. Digital regulatory and management agents. Coupling a complex system to its digitized hybrid model allows for the ability of agent-based systems to accomplish difficult real-world tasks such as oversight of construction and operations. For example, robotic-and dronedriven systems could oversee and inspect up to 100% of the construction in real-time, providing a much higher level of rigor in ensuring engineering quality at a lower cost and reduction in sensor placement.

Models can also be used to enable digital twin (DT) concepts that can provide predictive and protective capabilities. A DT is a computational model of a physical SSC. Being a virtual replica of it, a DT can act like the real SSC and assist in the interpretation of signatures and patterns, the testing of new settings, the simulation and analysis of all types of scenarios, and the execution of whatever may be needed in a virtual environment, knowing that what it is observed in the DT would also arise in the physical asset (i SCOOP, 2018). Typical applications benefiting from DDR -in ways that improve reliability, availability, maintainability, safety, and security (RAMS) and reduce costs and operational risks -include anomaly detection, diagnostics, and prognostics, root cause analysis, control, optimization, planning, visualization, commissioning, and training. DT technology may also assist in remote operation, maintenance, and repair of nuclear systems as well as provide feedback and insights for improving designs. Many of these DDR come together to give a 'complete' representation of the SSC at hand, i.e. ISA. Based on these anticipated benefits, it has been argued (Littlefield and Davidson, 2018) that there will be DTs for almost every SSC within every industry, including airplanes, manufacturing plants, power components, oil refineries, and transportation networks, with billions of components expected to be represented by DTs by 2021 (Panetta, 2017).

Consequently, the development of data structures is crucial for supporting SNS. The use of modern constructs (e.g., data ensembles) is anticipated, which are a collection of data sets created by SSC under time-varying conditions, including variables of different types (e.g., data, independent, condition). Similarly, other data structures may be utilized: distributed arrays, in which data reside in combined memory of clusters; graphics processing unit (GPU) arrays, in which data resides on GPU card memory; and tall arrays, which are large arrays stored within multiple files and disks. It is important to recognize that data calibration should be completed on all inputs prior to data acquisition in order to establish proper baselines. After data are calibrated, they may need to be further prepared to support diverse functionalities. For example, data may be filtered to remove instrumentation noise and outliers to provide sufficiently high levels of certainty and adequately acceptable accuracy rates. With the pervasive use of ML-based computational resources equipped with learning capabilities, record data sets may also need to be parsed for dataset training.

Fig. 10 illustrates an M&S and algorithm development process using the DT concept to support predictive M&C strategies that enable advanced nuclear reactor functionalities such as PM. In particular, a high-fidelity distributed digital replication (HFDR) is developed of the given SSC using M&S techniques, including finite element methods (FEM). Actual process responses are used to verify, tune, and validate this HFDR. With a validated HFDR, a predictive performance and maintenance engine is synthesized and tested. Even though this HFDR may be used for supporting processes running at the strategic and tactical levels (as introduced in Fig. 3), a model reduction procedure may be employed to convert HFDR into a reduced-fidelity digital replication (RFDR) with a more manageable complexity for real-time applications. The given RFDR may be constructed using hybrid M&S methods integrating physics-based models characterizing known dynamics with data-driven models characterizing unknown dynamics. This RFDR can then be used for implementing an SEI-driven predictive performance and maintenance engine running at the operations/ production levels depicted in Fig. 3 and close to the edge SSC under consideration.

To further illustrate the use of DDT, Fig. 11 depicts a sophisticated self-learning controller (based on EI techniques such as artificial neural networks, ANN) capable of learning the desired output response and delivering predictive control via the complementary use of a local, at the edge, digital replication. This self-learning controller may extend over several of the layers (e.g., control, production, and operations levels) depicted in Fig. 3. i.e. implementing a DDT architecture. The ANN controller is tuned via two complementary learning methods by: i) quantifying the residual between the output from the actual monitored SSC and the desired output response; and ii) utilizing the predictive output computed by the (already-tuned) digital replication of the given SSC when driven by the residual computed from comparing its output with the desired output response. The local DT potentially located at the edge device is tuned by a learning algorithm comparing its output from that outputted by the monitored SSC.

div.head: Embedded sensing and actuation devices
div.p: This thrust involves the development or adaptation (e.g., from other industries) of sensing and actuation technologies that can be embedded within complete smart devices. This accelerates the creation of smart sensing and actuation resources and devices that can communicate with one another and are enabled by the use of edge computing techniques.

In particular the concept of sensor-rich environments for ubiquitous sensing deployments has resulted in EI-driven advance- ments in many industries, advancement that would arguably be extremely beneficial for the nuclear industry. In fact, a sensorrich environment, with a multitude of sensors, is of paramount importance for achieving smart functionalities in nuclear systems, to encompass even autonomous operations. Fortunately, sensorrich environments are now feasible and cost-effective due to the miniaturization of high computational-processing power and networking capabilities embedded at the chip and device levels. These advancements have facilitated the deployment of smart sensors capable of self-awareness, self-decision-making, and self-adaptation. Thus, a benefit of securely implementing AI-enhanced capabilities at the sensors themselves using edge computing may be that of avoiding the need to send a large amount of data between the sensors located near the given edge SSC and a centralized data center or cloud computing system for processing, which may impair the delivery of smart sensors (and smart SSC) that can rapidly respond to critical situations in an informed way. On the other hand, edge computing may not be able to offer some of the attractive advantages for sensing provided by cloud computing such as cost effectiveness, scalability, flexibility, mobility, and accessibility, although at the expense of possibly degrading its cyber security and resiliency postures. The topic of edge computing is addressed further later in this article. A rich body of sensory data can also support DT concepts by providing a variety of measurements (e.g., temperature distribution through reactor cores, thermal component signatures, and vibrational frequencies) collected in real-time that can be used to update the states of digital-twin replications and increase understanding of the current conditions of the monitored SSC. Considerations should be taken to select sensors based upon a common platform in order to reduce acquisition cost and ensure availability of replacement sensors. Testing of the sensor networks, along with the verification and validation (V&V) of the algorithms, could be performed using both DDR and integrated testing within hardware-in-the-loop (HiL) environments.

Considering that numerous data formats may be used for recording measurements (e.g., CSV, XML, XLS, RDF, TXT), the standardization of data formats is a key element for implementing SNS. However, data formatting is only one aspect of achieving flexibility. Another aspect for achieving flexibility is to properly address the potential diversity in data fidelity and to quantify uncertainty, which is necessary for controlling and planning tasks. The level of available data fidelity depends on the level of digital instrumentation and control (DI&C) modernization deployed in a given nuclear system, matched with the fidelity of data collected in a nuclear plant, which should be higher than would be seen in an equivalent fossil-based power plant due to the regulatory regime for nuclear plants. However, these data are currently manually collected and are not used beyond the main intended purpose of the data, which is usually to demonstrate safety and regulatory compliance. In a typical operating LWR nuclear power plant in the US, fifteen sources of data are mostly manually collected. These data sources include process instruments and controls, maintenance activities, equipment performance testing, calibration, operator rounds, radiation protection, security, condition reporting, work orders, system-engineer notebooks, schedules, logistics, clearance orders, vendor and plant documentation, and industry operating experience. Data-collection methods can be automated by using autonomous methods. Details of how these methods can be automated can be found in Al- Rashdan and St-Germain (2018).

How a given SSC is managed in terms of data collection depends on whether it is passive or active. In particular, passive equipment is managed through dedicated aging-management program components while active components require surveillance procedures through equipment-specific procedures applied periodically. Active-component monitoring typically involves activities beyond an inspection (e.g., actual disassembly of equipment). SSCs in nuclear plants can be further categorized into rotating machinery (e.g., pumps, turbine, and generators), energy-transfer components (e.g., transformers, heat exchangers, and steam generators), actuators (e.g., valves), DI&C equipment (e.g., process transmitters, reactor controls, breakers, valve actuators), and passive components (e.g., pipes, cables, structures). Each SSC has unique models to reflect its functions and degradation mechanisms. Consequently, SEI must be component specific, with different techniques used for the different SSCs (e.g., Rashdan et al., 2018). While the majority of components in nuclear plants may be used in a manner similar to advanced reactors, these reactors will have technologyspecific components, or variations of the standard component used in a typical nuclear plant. For example, sodium-cooled reactors have electromagnetic pumps that are not used in LWR reactors. The migration to smart SSCs (i.e., SSCs with SEI as part of core operations, control, and maintenance) is expected to augment traditional components with additional sensors, controllers, and actuators that enable the equipment to behave more autonomously.

The need for data collection for SEI-ISA implementation require enhancing the fidelity of data in time and space. This goal can be achieved by automating data-collection methods to enable a continuous flow of data and developing new methods to increase data insights currently not available so as to enable continuous spatial coverage. To achieve these two objectives, new sensors (e.g., fiber optics) may need to be deployed, in addition to mobile, autonomous data-capturing technologies (e.g., drones), fixed datacapturing technologies (e.g., retrofitted sensors, smart equipment, or image processing technologies), or new methods of data mining and integration toward enabling extended use of existing data sources. Given the proliferation of data anticipated for new nuclear plants, there is a need to organize and analyze large data sets while keeping track of the systems and conditions the data represent. Data sources may include historians and real-time database management systems, which are typically secured by unidirectional information flow. However, traditional functions assuming that data are in memory may not be applicable in many cases, leading to the development of functions capable of utilizing large data sets running on computer clusters and cloud-based HPC.

Identifying the data needed to implement SEI and ISA requires considering the value of data and cost of collecting it, in addition to the feasibility (e.g., due to regulations, power, infrastructure, and practicality), data-communication infrastructure, computational power, storage, and data uses (e.g., the optimal spatial and time coverage of data acquisition to meet objectives). This includes considering data fusion arrangements in which algorithms based on several easily accessible features may outperform algorithms based on one expensive feature. The decision on data needs requires an economic and technical evaluation of data sources, and is therefore application specific. In this regard, it is crucial to recognize that not all sensors monitoring a given SSC provide useful information in support of a given objective (e.g., failure progression). Consequently, optimal sizing and placement of sensing and computational resources is key. SNS will require optimal integrated solutions to well-formulated multi-attribute problems that consider requirements and physical constraints where SSCs coexist if mission goals are to be achieved. To optimize resources, assure adequate O&M activities, and support both the computational and human agents while avoiding information saturation, for example, it is crucial that the selection of sensor suites (considering both resource locations and types) is conducted following a top-to-bottom, system-centric optimization approach, where mission objectives are clearly defined to drive optimal specifications of measurement needs, sensor placements, and sensor performance. This will be significantly influenced by the model-based constructs that are deployed, as predictive models may in some cases replace the need for measured data. It is then imperative that the performance, range, and resolution of distributed sensing is optimized for nuclear applications.

div.head: Adaptive security architectures
div.p: 1) Introduction: This thrust involves the development and validation of adaptive security architectures and proactive defense capabilities for effectively handling natural and malicious threats, as well as for the protection, detection, prediction, mitigation, and recovery from disturbances and anomalies including hybrid (physical plus digital) insults. This accelerates the integration of advanced digital-security and resiliency measures to tackle anomalies with an eye toward improving digital-security and resiliency postures of SNS by moving the nuclear industry from preventive and reactive fixes to predictive and proactive solutions.

Increased automation and connectivity provide myriad benefits, but also increases the risk of a malicious attack or automation dis-ruption due to administration or configuration errors. With no plan to abandon the tremendous gains in flexibility, productivity, and efficiency offered by EI, most, if not all, industries (including Oil and Gas O&G, manufacturing, transportation, energy and power generation) are moving and will continue to move forward with the ubiquitous use of EI in their processes and systems, while managing digital security concerns with the implementation of diversified portfolios of security controls in tailored, continuous, adaptive, security architectures and with the recognition of their differing security and resiliency goals.

Consequently, it is of paramount importance that digital security and resiliency are intrinsically integrated into the design of the operations management and DI&C systems of the given nuclear system. Embracing the notion of SEI by design is suggested as a proactive embedding of security and resiliency within the notional intelligent control framework illustrated in Fig. 4. Enabled by SEI techniques and technologies, resilient control systems can be designed to be proactive, rather than reactive, by predictively identifying incipient events and strategies to protect critical, vulnerable, or life-limited SSCs as means of ensuring continued dependable operation. Following an SEI-by-design strategy supporting ISA, highly-modeled, highly-monitored systems would ingrain anti-fragility features highly desired for advanced smart nuclear systems.

Fig. 12 illustrates a generalized proactive defense architecture in which M&C loops have been extended to address hybrid (digital and physical) disturbances, including malicious insults. Italic labels (in red) denote new elements (e.g., digital health and disturbances, risk/impact, quality metrics, time-varying, resilient M&C adaptation, M&C countermeasures) typically not considered in traditional M&C applications but included here to deal with hybrid threats. The numeric value on the left-top corner of a block denotes its order within the assumed information flow. Under operational scenarios considering malicious threats, disturbances can now compromise sensor and controller configurations, thus demanding resilient M&C adaptation and countermeasures as well as timevarying sensor and controller configurations.

From a digital security perspective, increasing the use of SEI and ISA in nuclear systems requires a significant digital transformation of technology infrastructure and resources. This digital transformation may increase attack surface exposure and the likelihood that digital events of any kind (security or administrative) may impact operations. In particular, multiple challenges arise when implementing highly-digitized M&C systems in high-consequence applications, including:

1. Traditional M&C applications, where disturbances are (generally) assumed to act exclusively on physical assets and can generally be well-characterized. Contrarily, malicious attacks, which are intrinsically ill-characterized, may involve manipulating both physical and digital assets, making attack and risk determination more complex in terms of devising security and resiliency solutions; 2. Traditional M&C applications, in which information is typically consumed in a deterministic manner. When responding to a digital event, regardless of origin (but after recognizing the possibility of malicious data manipulation), information may need to be consumed probabilistically and require analytic considerations prior to response. For example, operations systems have to consider whether process deviations are a result of natural or malicious actions. If the deviations continue and hit unacceptable boundaries, threat evaluation and proactive defense measures should be triggered to deliver corresponding security and resiliency analyses and responses; 3. Traditional M&C applications, where information typically involves a fixed set of sensing and controlling resources. Digital security and resiliency architectures for modern M&C implementations may however involve time-varying sets of resources. This challenge should be explicitly addressed in the risk management plan and considered when security life-cycle (design, implementation, maintenance, end-of-life) tasks are performed.

Operational and cybersecurity risk assessments support the premise that well-considered, carefully-implemented SEI-ISA capabilities may improve digital security risk management, in addition to enhancing operational performance and providing layers of observability that counter the increased attack surface. Incorporating automation techniques in the existing reliability and continuous improvement processes will not only increase operational resilience, but also address potential security concerns. To address digital security considerations due to hybrid (digital plus physical) threats in high-consequence, highly-digitized applications, modern M&C systems should be designed differently by including the following intrinsic properties in their architectural designs (Garcia and Lin, 2018): 1. Effective management of ill-characterized threats by, for example, utilizing diverse physical and digital health indicators to manage uncertainty and imprecision 2. Effective accommodation of partial, probabilistic, unreliable, or imprecise information by, for example, utilizing multimodal data fusion and probabilistic analysis to address challenging threat situations and behaviors; 3. Predictive and risk-informed dynamic selection of sensing and control resources by, for example, utilizing randomization and diversity in a manner that enhances digital security and resiliency, proactively complicates attack success, and recovers from attacks 4. Adaptive information generation and collection based on assessed SSC conditions by, for example, utilizing adaptive data marshalling toward the minimization of information needed to meet the desired level of assessment quality under particular conditions 5. Graceful performance degradation, as opposed to sudden collapse, when facing severe insults by implementing adaptable intelligence architectures capable of accommodating failure, tampering, and error tolerance as well as utilizing autonomous recovery mechanisms.

Numerous guides and standards have been provided, addressing security controls for ICS and information systems (e.g., NIST, 2015;NIST, 2014;NIST, 2013;DHS, 2016). However, RD&D effort is still needed in these areas to further strengthen existing or to develop new guidelines, practices, and standards beyond the administrative threat-centric conceptualization of security concerns and their preventive risk identification, quantification, and mitigation. The following three sections introduce additional particulars on the topics of digital security, resiliency, and integrated testing.

2) Digital security: Early studies of digital transformation in corporate IT identified four business innovation characteristics driving it: relative advantage, compatibility, costs, and digital security (Zhu et al., 2006). Digital transformation refers to how industries use digital techniques to transform themselves with a focus on becoming more adept at understanding how a business is run and can be improved, including in operational space (Hughes, 2018). It also requires horizontal and vertical integration of information, communications, and automation technology throughout the whole organization to address the complexity of today processes (Jamsa-Jounela, 2007). For similar reasons, industrial teams concerned with OT have begun to demand integration of operations and optimization efforts, thus impacting production networks and representing complete value-creating production chains (Jamsa-Jounela, 2007). Characteristics of industrial transformation include rising investment in automation technology, implementation of advanced SEI-ISA capabilities, and expanded demands for better shop-floor to top-floor communications.

As illustrated in Fig. 13, digital security risk is affected by the upswing in the number of data streams, work flows, and technology deployments associated with a transformed industrial envi-ronment. Digital risk mitigations appropriate to digital transformation in nuclear operations have not been widely tested yet, although this could change rapidly given the dynamic nature of security research. In particular, cyberattacks against nuclear operations were not commonly considered until Stuxnet was identified in 2010 (Shearer, 2010). However, Moonlight Maze (Thakur et al., 2016) detected in 1998 and attacks run by Markus Hess (McCartney, 1998) in 1986, unofficially named 'Operation Showerhead' in Stoll (2005, show that technical cyberattack capabilities have been under development for nearly 40 years. In all these cases, defensive and detection counter-measures were taken to identify similar attacks in the future and to mitigate risk presented to acceptable levels. The historical incidents suggest that: i) attack surface exposure is available for exploitation on high value networks regardless of technology type or level, kind of communications, and amount of data sharing; and ii) digital security risk to nuclear network with SEI-by-design capabilities may still be mitigated to acceptable levels with entirely new, digitalized, and cyber-aware nuclear systems.

The challenge of digital risk management is compounded by variations in focus, methods, and goals across industries. There is no single approach that can be applied across the board, with tailored approaches often failing if these efforts ignore the business goals of an organization and the engineering risk of the process. In this regard, technical risk assessments using standardized, methodical, and organized guides (NIST, 2012) and approaches (e.g., Risk Management Framework (RMF) (NIST, 2014) and REsponse Analysis and Characterization Tool (ReACT) ) may be performed on nuclear IT/OT networks and their anticipated implementation of SEI-ISA capabilities to characterize, assess, and mitigate cybersecurity risks. Preliminary technical security assessments suggest that cyber threat hazards related to SEI and ISA can be identified using a combination of operational and cybersecurity risk assessments. Research is needed regarding appropriate digital security and risk management for nuclear environments. Existing trends in digital security research tend to focus in three primary areas, namely: i) high-level technical design requirements; ii) threat or attack-centric conceptualization of security concerns; and iii) methods to identify risk or to calculate risk formulaically. This kind of research is critical to evolving digital nuclear security and risk management practices. Unfortunately, it is not highly actionable, leaving the engineering, process automation, IT/OT, or security teams, who design, implement, and maintain technical security architecture and controls, with a shortage of resources from which to learn or upon which to base work. New approaches to digital security and resilience are needed to address the need for actionable, technical security resources to ensure teams have both the data and knowledge to assess risk and secure digital assets.

Numerous risk analysis methodologies have been demonstrated that are relevant to SEI and ISA applications. For example, the approach presented in Garrick (1998) is an effective summary of risk management efforts and concerns in most automation environments not just nuclear power, space systems, and chemical processing. As relevant as this article was to engineering risk analysis at the time, it is equally applicable to digital security risk management for any CPS now, including nuclear CPS. In particular, Garrick (1998) identifies requirements necessary to characterize and manage digital security risk in nuclear operations networks; that is: ''A thorough understanding of the components and processes constituting an engineered system, along with a quantitative statement about the failures and scenarios important to risk, enable decision makers to properly allocate resources" (Garrick, 1998).

Several effective digital risk analysis techniques have been proposed in recent years to address concerns unique to CPS (e.g., Nourian and Madnick, 2018;Abdo et al., 2018). Each approach, however, depends on a range of SEI being made available, including: up-to-date asset and configuration (hardware, software) inventories; descriptions or digital representations of data flows, network traffic, and system dependencies; and performance data regarding digital resource performance in relation to operations or engineering design requirements. It is then crucial to understand how digital security and other factors may affect operational risk as illustrated in Fig. 13. To respond to operational risk, both digital probability and engineering impact need to be evaluated. Therefore, digital events, whether of administrative, operational, or security origins, affect the probability of an impact occurring. Put another way, cybersecurity information feeds probability calculations, not impact assessments. Digital risk analysis for CPS are likely to require a deeper understanding of relationships between the physical processes, digital resources, and work flows than existing digital security architecture and risk management models support. This is significant if digital risk can or should be offset with other types of engineering or process controls. New methods for identifying, developing, and analyzing these dependencies must be developed to support expanded risk analysis considerations. SEI combined with engineering design and hazards analysis has shown promising initial results for improving digital risk management, security architecture, and incident management in the CPS space based on these fundamental considerations.

In paradigms emphasizing attack-centric methods (as opposed to defender-focused capabilities), security efforts often begin with analyzing attacker capabilities. While threat information is imperative for characterizing emerging digital risk, the information is not always directly actionable by defenders. In fact, demonstrated that IT security operations teams and engineering teams responsible for routine security tasks often need help consuming attack-centric data to make it useful, i.e., allow them to get ahead of the threat curve. Developing adaptive defense-in-depth (DiD) security architectures or appropriate technical security controls for a CPS network requires blended analyses of technical threat characteristics and existing security capabilities, and granular understanding of component function within the process. Tools and risk analysis techniques (e.g., STIG) are needed to convert threat-focused information into actionable security plans.

Considering that SSC are governed by physical laws and that a sensor-rich environment is assumed for ISA, hybrid intrusion detection and protection system (IDPS) that combine both digital-and physical-based assessments are anticipated for advanced nuclear systems. Fig. 14 illustrates an architecture for implementing hybrid IDPS. Under this advanced digital security solution, threat detection and diagnosis are accomplished by holistically integrating observations and assessments based on collected digital and physical signatures, behaviors, and understandings.

Briefly, four main components are identified in Fig. 14: SSC Descriptor Database (SDD), Digital-based Threat Detection (DTD), Physics-based Threat Detection (PTD), and Holistic Digital-Physical Fusion (HDPF). In particular, the SDD describes a given SSC, hosting information that identifies its boundary, inputs, outputs, ports, sensors (e.g., a radiation detector), controllers (e.g., a PLC) and actuators (e.g., a valve), as well as governing equations characterizing key time-and event-driven dynamics. Package streams traveling on the particular control networks are collected and then deep inspected, extracting, not only important information such as identification of the senders generating the data (e.g., a given sensor) and of the targeted receivers (e.g., a given control system) receiving it but also payload info such values of process variables and command actions. With the information organized at SDD, the DTD detects potential intrusions by analyzing network behaviors (e.g., package frequency, package sender/re-ceiver pairs, and package sizes). Similarly, the PTD detects potential intrusions by analyzing payloads considering physicsbased semantics, such as whether a given sensor information makes sense from a physical perspective or whether a given command seems inappropriate as it may take the monitored SSC to an unacceptable, and potentially dangerous, operational region. The HDPF collects both digital and physical assessments and integrate them to determine whether an anomaly or intrusion exists and, if so, whether it is a digital, physical, or hybrid insults. By using digital-and physics-based signatures for intrusion assessment, known and collected understandings, and embedded systemtheoretic approaches based on SEI technologies, multiple benefits can be derived. Implementing this notional digital security architecture for hybrid IDPS in nuclear SSC that has SEI and ISA as emphases produces myriad benefits, including:

1. A holistic approach to protect nuclear systems and ICS 2. Complementary information security methods with systemtheoretic security methods 3. Exploitation of physical knowledge and understanding on CPS being monitored and controlled 4. Robust response to attacks undetectable and unidentifiable by traditional IDPS

The DDR concept can also be used here for adaptive defense against malicious attacks delivered to fool sensors and actuators. Assume that an attack is devised to manipulate a given control system associated with a targeted SSC to inflict an undesirable consequence. This control system, which is associated with a set of sensors and actuators, can be fooled in two ways, which rarely exist separately: by providing it with compromised data or by sending a command to a corresponding actuator to make the SSC do something with malicious intent. Typically, an adversary finds a way to act as a valid member in the system. Using this access, it sends false information out in a specific way that results in its ability to take down a system. A DT, including both physical and digital elements such as controls, is constructed to emulate the monitored SSC. Recognizing that physics must always be satisfied and that the data provided by sensors are related by physics, the DT, containing insights regarding the SSC, can be employed to assess sensor data by looking at both the data flow and related physics. If the signal provided by a potentially compromised sensor seems abnormal, the relationship between it and the other sensors will also look abnormal. This anomaly detection can be utilized to respond to an attack, even when multiple sensors are compromised. After a set of sensors has been assessed as being compromised, the DT may also be used to build and employ virtual analytical sensors for the purpose of substituting for the tampered devices and continuing operations of the compromised SSC until the problem is resolved. In this way, DDR concepts can be employed to enable three fundamental defense tasks against malicious insults, namely: i) detect, locate, and warn of an identified problem using known physics; ii) isolate a potentiallycompromised device (e.g., a sensor); iii) build and utilize a virtual device (e.g., an analytical sensor) to continue operations, possibly in a degraded manner but without being forced to end operations. This approach using enhanced state awareness provided by SEI and resulting in ISA is key to moving these 'intelligent systems' toward inherent digital security.

3) Digital resiliency: Sensing, communication, and control malfunctions are inevitable due to failures, aging, attacks, scheduled updates, and other stressors underpinning M&C functions. Reliance on the highly-digitized system architectures involved in nuclear applications of SEI and ISA, it is of paramount importance to assure that the performance of the given CPS is antifragile and degrades gracefully. A viable strategy to eliminate brittleness and increase mission-level resilience in nuclear systems is to make them robust at the mission level (i.e., as opposed to doing so at low-level controllers) and move the responsibility for real-time adaptive, and possibly reasoning behavior from operators to the intelligent control systems themselves. To tackle this need for so-called graceful degradation, mission-level resilience is required to address component failures and attacks and recover base capabilities after disturbances through FDI and recovery measures, including faulttolerance and run-time self-adaptation based on functional knowledge (e.g., Hernandez et al., 2018).
