It is in the correct and prompt autonomous response to anomalies that the introduction of SEI techniques within nuclear system designs becomes relevant in support of resiliency features for limiting the progression and cascading of anomalies, containing them, and minimizing the need for issuing intrusive commands affecting operations such as shutdowns. Fault/attack detection, diagnosis, and recovery may be used to address faults and perturbations out of the range of control operations.

Several resilient control architectures have been proposed integrating functional knowledge (within system models and databases) and autonomous supervision to implement fault tolerant control (FTC) and self-adaptation frameworks for augmented autonomy (e.g., Garcia and Lin, 2018;Garcia et al., 2015;Garcia et al., 2014;Lin et al., 2015). Some of them rely on physical (e.g., redundant sensors) and computational (e.g., redundant controllers) redundancy in the monitored SSC to replace faulty/ compromised components with alternatives that can perform a similar role. However, these FTC-related methods deployed to deal with anomalies mostly utilize fault-tolerant and self-adaptation solutions synthesized at the component level. Consequently, these fixed, case-based solutions designed for particular purposes cannot by themselves accommodate emergent, systemic threat response. In addition, they are expensive, non-scalable, and hard to maintain. To address this limitation, resiliency in controllers may be improved using reasoning patterns (e.g., Sanz et al., 2014) and may be important to advance SEI in nuclear systems.

Following the generalized proactive defense architecture illustrated in Fig. 12,Fig. 15 illustrates a robust M&C architecture to achieve this resiliency goal. This architecture, or pieces of it, may be distributed as needed at the supervisory, operational, and tacti-cal levels denoted in Fig. 3. In particular, four main components are depicted in Fig. 15, namely 'data-control quality assessment (DCQA)', 'mission', 'monitoring adaptation (MA)', and 'control adaptation (CA)'. In particular, the DCQA component assesses the quality of data and controls being collected, communicated, utilized, and generated within the given SSC. An unfavorable data quality (DQ) value may be quantified by cybersecurity measures for data if it violates an acquired understanding of ranges and trends, for example. Similarly, an unfavorable control quality (CQ) value may be assigned to a given controller if its control command may take the particular SSC to an undesired state (e.g., leading to instability and catastrophic failure). The mission component then interprets how these DQ and CQ values may affect the SSC mission as it related to risk and health, for example, and predict potential impacts. With assessments conducted at the Mission, the MA and CA components adapt M&C devices, respectively.

With respect to information devices, adaptation may manifest by optimizing sensor configurations, implementing moving target defense strategies to minimize threat surfaces, and executing data marshalling based on the level of situational alertness necessary for the assessed conditions of the given SSC. Proactive responses may involve reconfiguring to alternate sensor or control configurations to avoid incipient failures, for example, with the purpose of minimizing stresses on the suspect SSC. With respect to control devices, adaptation may manifest by initially using feedback controllers with full functionalities and then moving to less sophisticated control strategies that required less or even no data inputs (e.g., open-loop) as sensory information becomes increasingly compromised. Switching to hardwired control strategies of significantly less functionality may be desirable to maintain safe operation of the nuclear SSC at hand, but at a degraded condition, hence exhibiting the property of graceful degradation.

New affordable, maintainable, and scalable strategies and methods, supported by SEI techniques and technologies, engineering tools, and reusable assets, for resiliency and self-healing are required to provide adequate levels of dependability. Potential techniques include using mission-directed intelligent agents and DTs with simplified system characterizations describing processes, objectives, and KPI relevant for achieving the required levels for RAMSS. Being simulated faster-than-real time, a DT can be employed to deliver predictive information that can be used in multiple tasks, including monitoring, control, diagnosis, prognosis, security, and safety. In addition, automatic mechanisms should be incorporated to distribute information regarding failures, damaged or compromised components, and other anomalies within knowledge databases to update understanding and state awareness about the monitored plant and facilitate informed reasoning on reassessed conditions and mitigating actions.

Within a MAS approach enabling graceful degradation, a supervisory agent may use a model of the intelligent control system to detect, diagnose, and predict any deviation from expected behaviors and to determine appropriate corrective actions via reconfiguration. The loss of some functionality due to failures or attacks may lead to suboptimal asset management, but it will not prevent surviving agents from taking tolerable decisions based on partial or incomplete information. Likewise, if a data source becomes inaccessible or a given intelligent agent fails to perform its assigned task (e.g., asset monitoring or control), the other agents within the intelligent M&C system can autonomously continue their tasks and monitor or control the assets affected by the insults. In this manner, the integration of intelligent systems techniques within a MAS approach delivers an SEI-driven M&C approach that meets the requirements of flexibility, extensibility, robustness, and graceful degradation. After detecting a digital, physical, or hybrid attack, an alternate M&C strategy is needed for recovery and resiliency against tampering of measurements or control commands. Different recovery strategies may be used. For example, a physicsbased control strategy may be employed that warns the operator of violating commands and suggests (and automatically switches to) an alternate control algorithm. Mechanisms should also be integrated to deal when conflicts that occur whenever more than one rule suggesting potential solutions are simultaneously triggered.

div.head: Human-machine interfaces
div.p: This thrust involves the development or adaptation (e.g., from other industries) of advanced human machine interface (HMI) capabilities (e.g., conversational and augmented immersive reality systems) to significantly improve human-machine interactions. These HMI capabilities will radically enhance the way in which human communicate and interact with their engineered intelligent partners assigned to M&C nuclear systems.

In particular, SEI/ISA-driven HMI are usually autonomous, proactive, and social, often employing ML to be capable of adapting to new information or requests. Examples of advanced HMI technologies include conversational systems, augmented reality engines, and immersive reality systems. Most digital devices in multiple application areas are being increasingly designed to offer artificial intelligence (AI)-driven HMI capabilities. These approaches are also increasingly equipped with ML to make these agents more adaptive, not only to different input styles and new tasks, but also to accommodate different learning options leveraging supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and hybrid intelligence (where humans participate in the training process over time). In the development and application of conversational and augmented immersive reality systems for nuclear systems, it is important to define and assess their quality attributes and identify quality assurance approaches. In particular, quality attributes may be organized in terms of ISO 9241 (ISO, 2006) and NUREG 0700 (O'Hara et al., 2002) considering the concept of usability and addressing efficiency, effectiveness, and satisfaction. Each of these goals would be further subdivided in several categories. For example, quality attributes may include the performance and functionality, each including appropriate attributes as suggested in Radziwill and Benton (2017).

Similarly, quality assessment approaches incorporating metrics are needed to evaluate, prioritize, and select HMI products and solutions for nuclear applications. To this end, evaluation methods can be organized into four classes: qualitative analysis, quantitative analysis, pre-and post-testing, and competitions, with evaluations potentially using more than one evaluation method. Using quantitative analysis, comparisons among options and implementations may rely on the quantification of selected metrics and the prioritization process. Thus, two or more SEI/ISA-driven HMI systems can be compared by selecting the most significant quality attributes, or by analyzing them at two distinct points in time to determine whether the given quality has improved. This is particularly useful for adaptive HMI systems that learn when exposed to additional topics, experiences, and users (see e.g., Boring et al., 2019).

div.head: Augmented analytics and machine learning
div.p: This thrust involves the development, adaptation (e.g., from other industries), organization, and validation of hybrid AI methods and tech- nologies, including augmented data analytics and ML algorithms, for their utilization in nuclear SSC. This accelerates the creation of validated libraries of intelligent algorithms and tools for the nuclear industry.

Numerous techniques and combinations of them have been developed for the intelligent analysis and interpretation of data. For example, augmented analytics (see e.g., Sallam et al., 2018) uses ML/AI techniques to automate data preparation, insight discovery and sharing. Likewise, EC and ML have found fruitful areas for combining their corresponding strengths (see Zhang et al., 2011). Common techniques can be divided as physics-based, data-driven, and hybridization. With the ability to process large amounts of data, ML-based systems use automated and iterative algorithms to learn and solve a particular problem using supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement, apprenticeship, and other learning methods. Under a supervised method, it is assumed that the desired response or output of the ML system with respect to particular inputs is well known, with examples being provided and taught. Under an unsupervised method, the ML system finds on its own the correlations between data as they are propagated from inputs to outputs. An optimization objective function is used to interpolate or extrapolate trends from a learning dataset, to identify patterns and trends not readily visible using traditional statistical tools, and to understand and predict behaviors that the particular ML system was not explicitly programmed to understand. A ML system can thus be applied to a given monitoring, control, or preventive maintenance system that is smart enough to alter how it observes and controls a machine in response to changing conditions. Similarly, an important application of ML is in the area of hyper-parameter optimization (e.g., Bergstra and Bengio, 2012). Given its broad applicability, multiple ML and evolutionary computation (EC) algorithms have been developed, including ANN, fuzzy logic, self-organizing maps, genetic algorithms (GA), casebased reasoning, and ambient-intelligence. ML algorithms are often termed as 'universal approximators', capable of learning behaviors and patterns in data of an SSC under examination from an adequate training dataset. Being data-driven, ML techniques are non-parametric, non-linear, and multivariate learning algorithms that do not need to know a priori the functional form of the SSC under observation as required by traditional algorithms such as least-squares fitting. When training is performed, it is important to ensure that the quality of the ML fit to the particular problem can be independently assessed. To improve their performance, ML algorithms can typically be first trained with multiple models on the same data and then their predictions are averaged. Unfortunately, making predictions using a whole ensemble of models is cumbersome and may be computationally expensive. A practical solution is to use a compression technique to distill the knowledge in an ensemble of NN into a single model, which is much easier to deploy as suggested in Hinton et al. (2014). To this end, numerous platforms are available for the development of learning models as reported in Hatcher and Yu (2018).

To illustrate how AI algorithms accordingly validated and organized within specific libraries of tools may be applied to satisfy specific nuclear applications, Fig. 16 depicts a notional block diagram for implementing an inference system that uses SEI techniques. This inference system may include optimization and learning routines validated against specific nuclear applications to determine optimal membership functions for the learning-based, physics-informed control system that satisfy data-and physicsbased constructs stored in the knowledge base that were specifically constructed for addressing particular nuclear SSC applications.

div.head: Advanced edge computing and communication
div.p: This thrust involves the development or adaption (e.g., from other industries), organization, and validation of computing and communication capabilities to support the dissemination of advanced and edge computing in nuclear systems capable of accommodating the intelligent functions addressed under introduced RD&D opportunities. These computational and communication capabilities are expected to improve the latency, reliability, and efficiency of intelligent SEI-driven processes distributed across SSC. This thrust also involves the development of interface standards and guidance facilitating resource interoperability within modular architectures, cohesive system structures, and flexible interfaces.

In particular, utilizing SEI technologies within the notional intelligent M&C architecture illustrated in Fig. 4 will involve adding more hardware and software resources than those used in current nuclear fleets. However, the complexity of the SEI-driven program varies depending on how much smart functionality is desired, with SEI-assisted controllers often capable of being implemented with low-capability microcontrollers. Similarly, hardware and software improvements will allow for larger data sets to be processed more efficiently. Very fast processing capabilities will speed response time in addressing potentially catastrophic events. Edge computing is a topology in which information processing and content collection and delivery are placed closer to the sources of information (e.g., sensors) and the executers of actions (e.g., actuators). Data are collected and analyzed locally. By keeping information flow local to the extent possible, edge computing delivers multiple benefits, including reduction of latency and improvement of robustness and resiliency. The advent of GPU has enormously facilitated the implementation of very sophisticated SEI-driven functionalities at the device level. While a central processing unit (CPU) core is more powerful than a GPU core, the vast majority of this power goes unused by ML applications. A CPU core is designed to support an extremely broad variety of tasks whereas a GPU core is optimized exclusively for data computations. Because of this singular focus, a GPU core is simpler and has a smaller die area than a CPU, allowing many more GPU cores to be crammed onto a single chip. In fact, GPUs have almost 200 times more processors per chip than a CPU. Likewise, tensor processing units (TPU) and other AI accelerators with symbolic math libraries specifically designed for computing tensors involved in ML applications (e.g., ANN) may be employed. Consequently, SEI-ISA applications expected to perform large numbers of computations on a vast amount of data can see huge (e.g., 10 to 1000 times) performance improvements with GPU and TPU.

Through edge computing, smart sensor systems like that illustrated in Fig. 17 can be deployed that combine sensing with intelligence and real-time analytics (embedded in the inference engine), and fundamental understanding of the monitored SSC (embedded in the knowledge database) for improved performance, early warnings, and more accurate and robust output from collected input signals. Measurements collected by a smart sensor system are analyzed locally by the inference engine, which is supported by a knowledge base to compute: i) direct and indirect (analytical) sensor values; ii) health conditions of sensors in support of executing voting methods and calibration schemes; and iii) performance metrics, including data qualifiers such as data quality (DQ), which could be used to compute advanced notions (e.g., believability) to adaptively select which data to collect (Garcia et al., 2014).

Capitalizing again from edge computing, Fig. 18 illustrates a hierarchical control assembly specifically designed to deliver a control system with auto-tuning capability, i.e., adjusting its own control gains. In this figure, the inner control loop, running at a fast computational rate, is governed by a lower-level controller that, based on the residual calculated between the desired and sensed output responses, computes control signals to directly regulate the monitored SSC. The outer control loop, running at a slower computational rate, is governed by a higher-level controller (con-sisting of an optimizer and a knowledge database) that, based on performance metrics quantified in real-time, updates the control gains to be used by the lower-level controller. The complementary use of these two controllers results into a self-tuning (hierarchical) control assembly implemented in a local microprocessor that might be located at the specific edge component (e.g., a diesel genset). Given the computed values for defined performance metrics and information stored or accumulated in its knowledge database, an optimizer conducts optimization routines to identify optimal gains for the lower-level controller to best meet desired performance objectives. This auto-tuned lower-level controller may have a hybrid topology, integrating physics-based and data-driven methods. Auto-tuning of model parameters and control gains can also be achieved using SEI-driven methods for optimization through EI techniques like GA or particle-swarm optimization (PSO).

To implement the notional intelligent M&C architecture illustrated in Fig. 4, a robust physical infrastructure that can support a reliable and timely flow of data, information, knowledge, decisions, and controls is necessary. For assuring effective management of the large volumes of data expected, new communication guidelines may also be needed for moving data, via both wired and wireless channels, among sensors, databases, and intelligent systems distributed throughout the monitored SSC and supporting a robust and flexible data communication, management, and storage framework. Several data communication protocols and standards should be considered here. For example, within wireless communication technologies, matured data protocols (e.g., Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers [IEEE] 802.11 (IEEE, 2018), 802.15.4, (IEEE, 2017 and International Society of Automation (ISA, 2010) offer digital-secure, low-power data-transmission solutions.

div.head: Integrated testing platforms
div.p: This thrust involves the development and availability of integrated testing environments (e.g., national digital systems testing frameworks, call-back centers, simulators) where SEI-driven techniques and technologies can be validated, including those related to risk (e.g., common cause failures, CCF) and digital security and resiliency. The testing platform enables every SNS function or activity be verified and validated at all levels of the SNS, i.e. from an SSC level to the integrated nuclear system level.

In an integrated testing environment, sensing, actuation, and computational resources executing SEI-driven technologies are evaluated within a hybrid framework that includes both computational and physical assets. While computational assets may embody simulated SSC (e.g., a nuclear reactor core) at sufficient fidelity and granularity, a physical asset may be an actual SSC (e.g., a heat exchanger). With the creation of testing centers, data streams collected from, for example, diverse microreactor designs can be collected for integrated analysis, learning, and training. Fur- thermore, these testing environments can be used for gathering information about dangerous or catastrophic events so that data may also be available to train the models. It is also important to follow a well-defined and structured design process, not only for identifying the implications and impacts on risk, digital security, and digital resiliency aspects resulting from the ubiquitous integration of SEI technologies in nuclear systems, but also for incrementally suggesting and evaluating mitigation strategies that can assure the cost-effective achievement of risk, digital security, and digital resiliency goals specified for the nuclear SSC under examination.

Fig. 19 illustrates an integrated testing framework that can be used iteratively for evaluating SEI-driven techniques in nuclear SSC and devise mitigation measures for achieving the desired postures regarding risk, performance, digital security, and digital resiliency. In particular, the nuclear SSC under examination (e.g., a given microreactor design) is identified, triggering the execution of two main activities: vulnerability and diversity and defensein-depth (V3D) assessment as well as physical-digital performance and security evaluation (PSE). In V3D, techniques are applied to identify risks and vulnerabilities latent in a nuclear SSC under examination. In PSE, a comprehensive performance, risk, and vulnerability evaluation of the nuclear system is conducted, which benefits from the findings obtained from V3D. With this characterization in place, mitigation strategies are identified and selected, which may include administrative (e.g., incident response plan and training), static (e.g., functional/hardware D3), and proactive (e.g., DTs, hybrid IDPS, reconfiguration) mitigation measures. Then, a dynamic physical-digital testbed is developed for integrated testing. This testbed includes, not only key physical and digital elements associated with the nuclear SSC under examination, along with identified uncertainties, but also the developed SEI-driven techniques and mitigation strategies to assure specified acceptable error-margins. The physical-digital testbed is then subjected to diverse hybrid (malicious and non-malicious) test scenarios and its performance is quantified by computing defined metrics. This quantification is then used to determine whether the nuclear system under examination meet requirements within defined constraints and identify any additional risk or uncertainties. The nuclear SSC under evaluation may be re-characterized by adding findings, and this loop repeats by identifying and implementing new or modified mitigation measures as needed until requirements for performance, safety, security, and resiliency are met.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This article has defined key features of a deliberate approach at SEI and resulting ISA, providing definition of key terms and con-cepts, and providing a suggested framework for design and implementation. Challenges and risks are discussed. Potential outcomes (functionalities) afforded by deliberate implementation of SEI and ISA in advanced nuclear reactors could be disruptive, providing unprecedented levels of simplicity and cost reduction. SNS represent a promising alternative to traditional nuclear implementations, anticipated to deliver significant benefits to the nuclear industry in multiple ways. The discussed SEI/ISA-assisted nuclear systems are expected to be capable of continuous learning and reasoning in uncertain, imprecise, and challenging environments, exploiting a balance tolerance to achieve unprecedented robustness and tractability at a lower cost than traditional solutions. The ubiquitous use of SEI is anticipated to offer opportunities for adaptable and evolvable systems and functionalities. The more intelligent a nuclear system is engineered to be, the more productive it will be during operations with less downtime and safer and more secure responses.

The ever-changing nature in the use of energy within increasingly more integrated grids and markets makes it challenging to cost-effectively operate nuclear reactors within dynamic regimes. SNS equipped with SEI and ISA are anticipated to enable the automation of many tasks currently performed by operators, while providing explanations on applicable and selectable decisions and actions. Furthermore, the secure embedding of intelligence and the achievement of ISA in nuclear systems will facilitate information exchange across multiple engineering boundaries and energy resources, which will improve the timeliness and quality of decision-making. However, achieving high levels of autonomy for nuclear systems will require mission-directed intelligent agents, including computational observers, controllers, and decisionmakers, that can provide sophisticated foundational capabilities. The use of modern predictive analytics including ML is expected to be beneficial in managing nuclear processes as well as supporting datamining functions for training and improving designs via insights automatically collected from lessons learned. While the particular choice of architecture and framework for incorporating SEI and ISA in nuclear SSC may depend to some degree on the application at hand, large portions of it and its components as those suggested here are envisioned to be widely reusable and scalable.
